answers.answer: With the severe weight loss and not eating, your cat needs immediate veterinary care. Potential causes for her illness include kidney failure, diabetes, cancer, or poorly regulated hyperthyroidism. If her bloodwork and thyroid levels have not been checked recently since the thyroid medication was started a year ago, then they need to be checked. Depending on results, she may benefit from intravenous fluids and medications to stimulate her appetite.Good luck,Kimberly Coyner, DVM DACVD

question: My 17 year old hyperthyroid kitty stopped eating yesterday.  She is still dirinking water, but seems weak.  I found her sleeping in the shower yesterday which is a place that she has never slept before.  She would normally run from my dog, but when approached yesterday she didn't budge and only let out a weak meow.  She was diagnosed with severe hyperthyroid disease about a year ago.  I have been treating her with prescription meds ever since.  She got lethargic this summer, but rallied in about a week.  She has since stopped grooming herself and developed severe mats in her fur.  She has also dropped an incredible amount of weight over the last several months.  I can touch my index finger to my thumb when circling her lower spine.  All this and she has remained brighteyed and responsive until yesterday.  So,...I don't know if she will rally from this one or not.  I don't think she is in pain, but how would I know for sure?  She is not crying, just laying around a lot.  She is still getting up when I approach and moving around the house some.
title: My 17 year old hyperthyroid kitty has become lethargic
